items.content_html: I just can’t seem to go more than 4 minutes without buggy software bringing my work to a crashing halt.
Even more than usual, today I am proud to be a Californian.
I haven’t been able to ride my bike down the coast all month; first I had a cold, then I traveled, and then I got the flu. It hasn’t been the best January.

If you’re not failing, you’re not trying. The goal is not to eliminate failure entirely—it’s to minimize the impact (and perhaps frequency, to whatever extent is possible) of failure. Learn and proceed.
Call me an old crank if you will, but I just am not attracted to the idea of talking to a computer.

items.title: YouTube Serves Crypto-Mining Ads
items.content_html: Ads can be much more than an annoyance. Sometimes they provide a handy window for attackers to get into your computer, even on sites you think you can trust. Stop contributing to the online advertising economy: find indie sites that provide a useful service, and pay them for that service.
If you believe the FBI’s B.S. about being completely hamstrung by their inability to backdoor encryption on smartphones, ask yourself what they did before cellular phones existed.

If you run a Web server, don’t forget to set up DNS to handle your domain(s) with and without a www prefix. The first twenty years of the Web really hammered the whole www thing into people’s heads, perhaps permanently.
